sections.text:
# 5.3 Two agents 

We next obtain that, in the case of any two risk-seeking EU agents, a competitive equilibrium exists for any initial endowments. Moreover, this result also illustrates the non-uniqueness of the equilibrium price.

Proposition 4. Suppose $n=2$ and Assumptions ER and EURS hold. For any initial endowment vector $\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{2}(X)$, there exists a competitive equilibrium $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}, Q\right)$, where

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} Q}{\mathrm{~d} \mathbb{P}}=\frac{u_{1}(X)}{X} \frac{1}{\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}(X) / X\right]} \quad \text { with the convention } 0 / 0=0
$$

The equilibrium price in (7) has the form of (5) with $\left(\lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}\right)=(1,0)$. Since the positions of agents 1 and 2 are symmetric, we immediately get another equilibrium price by replacing $u_{1}$ in (5) with $u_{2}$. Therefore, the equilibrium price is generally not unique, unless $u_{1}=u_{2}$ (seen in Theorem 6). Different equilibrium prices correspond to different equilibrium allocations, but they can be derived from the same vector of initial endowments. Therefore, for a given set of initial endowments, the competitive equilibrium is generally not unique, which is in contrast to the case of strictly risk-averse agents, where often a unique competitive equilibrium can be derived from given initial endowments.

The proof techniques for Proposition 4 do not generalize to the case of $n \geq 3$ agents because our construction of the equilibrium (jackpot) allocation $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)=\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right)$ heavily relies on the ratio $u_{1}(x) / u_{2}(x)$. Roughly speaking, we choose $A_{1}$ as the event when $u_{1}(X) / u_{2}(X)$ is large, and choose $A_{2}$ as the event when $u_{1}(X) / u_{2}(X)$ is small; this intuition is similar to part (iv) of Theorem 2, but its generalization to $n \geq 3$ agents is unclear.

# 6 Rank-dependent utility agents 

The previous two sections considered agents that are globally risk seeking. While this assumption was conceptually interesting, more realistic models are needed for applications. We now analyze the problem of sharing risk among RDU agents, which are empirically more relevant. These agents have some local risk-seeking behaviour, but overall they are neither risk seeking nor risk averse. We will mainly focus on Pareto optimality in this section, as deriving competitive equilibrium for RDU agents seems to be beyond the reach of current techniques; an exception is Proposition 5, which offers an explicit competitive equilibria in a special setting. Admittedly, we will make some strong assumptions, but our results lead to interesting new economic insights on risk sharing that were not discovered before. The two main assumptions that we make are: All agents have the same RDU preferences, and their utility function is concave on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$and linear on a bounded interval $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$.

We first describe the RDU model. As in Sections 4 and 5, we consider nonnegative bounded random variables, by letting $\mathcal{X}=L_{+}^{\infty}$. A function $h:[0,1] \rightarrow[0,1]$ is called a probability weighting function if it is increasing and satisfies $h(0)=0$ and $h(1)=1$. For a probability weighting function $h$ and an increasing function $u: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$(i.e., a utility function), the RDU preference functional is given by

$$
\mathcal{U}(Y)=\int u(Y) \mathrm{d}(h \circ \mathbb{P})=\int_{0}^{\infty} h(\mathbb{P}(u(Y)>x)) \mathrm{d} x, \quad Y \in \mathcal{X}
$$

Here, the integral $\int u(Y) \mathrm{d}(h \circ \mathbb{P})$ is in the sense of Choquet. An RDU agent has its preference functional given by (8) for some probability weighting function $h$ and utility function $u$. When the utility function $u$ is linear, the RDU agent has the dual utility functional of Yaari (1987), denoted by

$$
\rho_{h}(Y)=\int Y \mathrm{~d}(h \circ \mathbb{P}), \quad Y \in \mathcal{X}
$$

The RDU functional in (8) is thus given by $\mathcal{U}(Y)=\rho_{h}(u(Y))$. An RDU agent is risk seeking if $h$ is concave and $u$ is convex, and is risk averse if $h$ is convex and $u$ is concave; see Chew et al. (1987). For nonnegative random variables, the RDU model coincides with the cumulative prospect theory of Tversky and Kahneman (1992) with reference point 0.

The most empirically relevant probability weighting functions $h$ are concave-convex (also called inverse S-shaped), that is, $h$ is continuous and there exists a point $p \in[0,1]$ such that $h$ is concave on $(0, p)$ and convex on $(p, 1) .{ }^{14}$ Clearly, such a probability weighting function leads to an RDU model that is neither risk averse nor risk seeking. Indeed, the interpretation of such a probability weighting function is risk seeking for small probability events and risk averse for moderate to large

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{14}$ If $p=0$ then $h$ is convex, and if $p=1$ then $h$ is concave.

Figure 3: An example of a utility function (left panel) and a probability weighting function (right panel) satisfying Assumption H-RDU for $n \geq 8$ and condition (10).
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)
(a) $u=a x$ on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ and $u(x)=a \log x+a$ on $\left[x_{0}, \infty\right)$ for some $a>0$, with $x_{0}=1$
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)
(b) $h=h_{\mathrm{TK}}$ with $\gamma=0.71$ (black curve) and $\bar{h}$ (blue curve); $h=\bar{h}$ on $\left[0, \beta_{h}\right]$ with $\beta_{h}=0.133$
probability events, as empirically observed from human behaviour. Tversky and Kahneman (1992) introduced the following class of concave-convex probability weighting functions

$$
h_{\mathrm{TK}}(t)=\frac{t^{\gamma}}{\left(t^{\gamma}+(1-t)^{\gamma}\right)^{1 / \gamma}}, \quad t \in[0,1]
$$

where $\gamma \in(0,1)$ is a parameter, empirically estimated to be 0.71 by Wu and Gonzalez (1996). ${ }^{15}$
For a probability weighting function $h$, we denote by $\bar{h}:[0,1] \rightarrow[0,1]$ the concave envelope of $h$, that is,

$$
\bar{h}(t)=\inf \{g(t): g \geq h \text { on }[0,1] \text { and } g \text { is concave }\}
$$

which is a concave probability weighting function. Since $\bar{h} \geq h$, we have $\rho_{\bar{h}}(Y) \geq \rho_{h}(Y)$ for all $Y \in \mathcal{X}$. For a concave-convex probability weighting function $h$, its concave envelope $\bar{h}$ coincides with $h$ on an interval $\left[0, \beta_{h}\right] \subseteq[0,1]$ (possibly empty) and it is linear on $\left[\beta_{h}, 1\right]$; see panel (b) of Figure 3. With the above background, we now make the main assumption on our homogeneous RDU agents.

Assumption H-RDU. Each agent $i \in[n]$ is an RDU maximizer with utility function $u$ and probability weighting function $h$, where $u$ is increasing and concave on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$and linear on an interval $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ with $u(0)=0$ and $u\left(x_{0}\right)>0$, and $h$ is concave-convex with $h=\bar{h}$ for $t \in[0,1 / n]$. The domain of allocations is chosen as $\mathcal{X}=L_{+}^{\infty}$. The total risk $X \in \mathcal{X}$ satisfies $\mathbb{P}(X>0)>0$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{15}$ The value of $\gamma$ has been estimated between 0.6 and 0.8 from different experiments by many authors including Tversky and Kahneman (1992); see Wu et al. (2004) for a summary.

Figure 3 depicts one pair $(u, h)$ that satisfies Assumption H-RDU. Using concave $u$ and concaveconvex $h$ in RDU models is standard and empirically appealing, as in Tversky and Kahneman (1992). The linearity of $u$ on the interval $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ is technically helpful to employ Theorem 1. The interpretation is $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ represents small-scale payoffs, for which the agent has a linear utility function, which is arguably realistic, as all differentiable utility functions are locally linear. This condition can be generalized to the weaker condition of convexity on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$; see Appendix D. The condition that $h=\bar{h}$ on $[0,1 / n]$ is equivalent to $n \geq 1 / \beta_{h}$, which is easily satisfied for large $n$. Using $\gamma=0.71$ in (9), we have $h=\bar{h}$ for $t \in[0,0.133]$ as depicted in panel (b) of Figure 3. Here, $n \geq 8$ is sufficient for this condition. This also implies that $h$ is concave on $(0,1 / n)$, and we will later use strict concavity of $h$ on $(0,1 / n)$ for some statements on strict domination. The conditions on the set $\mathcal{X}$ and the total wealth $X$ are the same as in Assumption EURS.

The next result shows the surprising fact that the previous statement about Pareto optimality for risk-seeking agents can also be obtained for the RDU agents, who are not risk seeking. We will compare a jackpot allocation $X \mathbf{J}$ with the proportional allocation $\overline{\mathbf{X}}:=(X / n, \ldots, X / n)$. In the next result, the condition $X \leq x_{0}$ should be interpreted as $\mathbb{P}\left(X \leq x_{0}\right)=1$, and the following technical condition is used in part (iii):

$$
\limsup _{t \downarrow 0} \frac{h(t / n)}{h(t)}<1, \quad h(1 / n)<1, \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{u(x / n)}{u(x)}=1
$$

In (10), the condition on $h$ holds for $h_{\mathrm{TK}}$ in (9), and the condition on $u$ holds for concave utility functions $u$ that are exponential or logarithmic on $\left[z_{0}, \infty\right)$ for some $z_{0}>0$ (see panel (a) of Figure 3 ), as well as any bounded utility functions.

Theorem 7 (RDU). Suppose that Assumptions ER and H-RDU hold. Let $\mathbf{J} \in \mathbb{J}_{n}$ be independent of $X$ satisfying $\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{J}]=\mathbf{1} / n$.
(i) If $X \leq x_{0}$, then the jackpot allocation $X \mathbf{J}$ is Pareto optimal and sum-optimal.
(ii) If $X \leq x_{0}, n \geq 2$, and $h$ is strictly concave on $(0,1 / n)$, then $X \mathbf{J}$ strictly dominates $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$.
(iii) If (10) holds, then there exists $y_{0}>0$ such that for $X \geq y_{0}, \overline{\mathbf{X}}$ strictly dominates $X \mathbf{J}$.
(iv) If $X$ is a positive constant, $u$ is strictly increasing and differentiable on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, and $h$ is strictly concave on $(0,1 / n)$, then $\overline{\mathbf{X}}-\varepsilon \mathbf{1}+n \varepsilon \mathbf{J}$ strictly dominates $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$ for $\varepsilon>0$ small enough.

Part (i) of Theorem 7 gives the Pareto optimality of a jackpot allocation even if the agents are not risk seeking. The key intuition to prove this statement is to notice that, for the jackpot allocation $X \mathbf{J}$, the probability of winning the jackpot is $1 / n$, and hence the condition $h=\bar{h}$ on

$[0,1 / n]$ implies that each RDU agent's utility for this particular allocation remains the same if we replace $h$ with $\bar{h}$. Then, we can use Theorem 1 to prove that this allocation is indeed optimal for the hypothetical RDU agents using $\bar{h}$, who are risk seeking due to the linear $u$ on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$, and then use this to show the optimality for the non-risk-seeking agents. Parts (iii) and (iv) do not require the assumption on linearity of $u$ on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$, which is clear from the proof.

To interpret Theorem 7, let us consider $X$ as a total prize to share. In parts (i) and (ii), the RDU agents tend to gamble against each other when the total prize is small, i.e., taking values in $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$. In particular, such a jackpot allocation is better for every agent when compared with the proportional allocation $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$. However, when the total prize is large enough, as in (iii), it is no longer optimal to use the jackpot allocation, which is strictly dominated by the proportional allocation. It could even be optimal to share proportionally if the utility function has a satiation point (see Example 5 below). Part (iv) considers the case of a constant total wealth $X$ to share. The countermonotonic (but not jackpot) allocation $\overline{\mathbf{X}}-\varepsilon \mathbf{1}+n \varepsilon \mathbf{J}$ can be interpreted as follows: On top of the constant allocation $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$, every agent pays a fee of $\varepsilon$ to enter a lottery returning $n \varepsilon$ to one randomly selected winner. When $\varepsilon$ is small, this represents a small-stake gamble. Thus, a small-stake gamble is always better than a proportional constant allocation. This observation holds true regardless of the total wealth level, in contrast to parts (i)-(iii).

To summarize these observations, the RDU agents tend to gamble when the stake is small (say, a few hundred dollars), and they may share proportionally, or almost proportionally, when the stake is large (say, several million dollars). This is consistent with empirical observations on risk attitudes: For instance, as observed by Markowitz (1952, p. 153-154), for lottery prizes with equal mean, people tend to choose the risky option for small stakes, and choose the safe option for large stakes. ${ }^{16}$ A similar empirical evidence is observed by Jullien and Salanié (2000). This result helps to explain the wide existence of small-stake gambles, such as lotteries, sport betting, and casinos.

Example 5. Assume that $u$ is constant on $\left[y_{0}, \infty\right)$ for some $y_{0}>x_{0}$; that is, $u$ has a satiation point. If $X \geq n y_{0}$, then $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$ is Pareto optimal because it yields the maximum utility for every agent, and it strictly dominates any jackpot allocation when $h(1 / n)<1$ (formally proved in Appendix B).

Some technical discussions are useful. Unlike the case of Theorem 2, we are not able to show that all Pareto-optimal allocations are jackpot allocations or that they are $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$-optimal; this is due to the non-linearity and nonconvexity in probabilistic mixtures of the RDU functionals. ${ }^{17}$ We do

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{16}$ Markowitz (1952) used a convex-concave utility function in the EU model to explain this for an individual agent. Our utility function is concave, and the gambling behaviour is due to the probability weighting function $h$. If we assume an EU model with a convex-concave utility function of Markowitz (1952) that is convex on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$, then the phenomenon remains to hold; see the proof in Appendix D.
    ${ }^{17}$ The functional $\rho_{h}$ is convex in probabilistic mixtures if and only if $h$ is concave; see e.g., Wang et al. (2020, Theorem 3).

not know whether the UPS is convex. Some extensions of Theorem 7 are discussed in Appendix D. In particular, the conclusions hold for utility functions $u$ such that $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ increases on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$, which is weaker than assuming either linearity or convexity on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$. This allows our result to accommodate convex-concave utility functions, which are found empirically plausible by Jullien and Salanié (2000) using cumulative prospect theory (which is RDU when considering gains).

We have not yet discussed competitive equilibria in this section, because we do not have general results. Nevertheless, in a special case where $X$ is a constant in $\left(0, x_{0}\right]$, we can show that $X \mathbf{J}$ is an equilibrium allocation, and the corresponding equilibrium price is the objective probability $\mathbb{P}$.

Proposition 5. Suppose that Assumptions ER and H-RDU hold, $X=x$ is a constant in $\left(0, x_{0}\right]$, and the vector of initial endowments $\boldsymbol{\xi}=\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(x)$ satisfies $\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right] \leq x \beta_{h}$ for all $i \in[n]$. Then $(x \mathbf{J}, \mathbb{P})$ is a competitive equilibrium, for any $\mathbf{J} \in \mathbb{J}_{n}$ satisfying $\mathbb{E}[x \mathbf{J}]=\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\xi}]$.

It is not surprising that $\mathbb{P}$ is the equilibrium price, as the total endowment is constant across all states. Although we assume that there is no aggregate uncertainty, the initial endowments in Proposition 5 can be random.

Recall that $\beta_{h} \geq 1 / n$ under Assumption H-RDU. Hence, $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)=(X / n, \ldots, X / n)$ satisfies the condition in Proposition 5, and the corresponding equilibrium allocation is $X \mathbf{J}$ with $\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{J}]=\mathbf{1} / n$ as in Theorem 7. The condition $\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right] \leq x \beta_{h}$ means that each agent's initial endowment is not too large compared to the total endowment $x$. Intuitively, agents tend to gamble for small-probability payoffs, which is the case when they have similar initial endowments. On the other hand, if one agent has a relatively large initial endowment, say $0.9 x$, then it is no longer optimal for this agent to gamble, because the utility of $0.9 x$ is $0.9 u(x)$, and the utility of $x \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}$ with $\mathbb{P}\left(A_{1}\right)=0.9$ is $h(0.9) u(x)$. Typically $h(0.9)<0.9$ (see Figure 3), representing risk aversion for large-probability payoffs. In this case, $(x \mathbf{J}, \mathbb{P})$ is not a competitive equilibrium, and we do not know whether equilibria exist.

# 7 Conclusion 

The results in this paper lay a foundation for studying risk sharing with risk-seeking agents and other agents with local risk-seeking behaviour. We anticipate that the counter-monotonic improvement theorem (Theorem 1) will lead to other fruitful directions of future study.

It would be useful to summarize what we know and what we do not. Pareto-optimal allocations and equilibrium allocations for risk-seeking EU agents are fully characterized, and the corresponding welfare theorems are established (Theorems 2 and 4). The case of homogeneous EU agents is even better understood, as we can fully describe the utility possibility frontier (Theorem 3) and the com-

petitive equilibria (Theorems 5 and 6). For a given vector of initial endowment and heterogeneous agents, the existence of competitive equilibria is not proved in general; a potential approach and a special case are discussed in Appendix E. For homogeneous RDU agents with concave-convex probability probability weighting functions, we obtain some Pareto optimal allocations for small-stake payoffs (Theorem 7), but we are not able to offer a complete characterization of Pareto-optimal allocations. We obtain one result on competitive equilibria for RDU agents with no aggregate uncertainty (Proposition 5). General results on competitive equilibria or heterogeneous RDU agents are unavailable. We believe that addressing these open questions requires highly nontrivial analysis.

In most results, we interpreted payoffs and allocations as financial gains. Symmetric results for losses can be derived, with scapegoat allocations in place of jackpot allocations.

To expand the scope, it is natural to investigate whether Pareto-optimal allocations are counter-monotonic in the context of sharing payoffs where agents have heterogeneous beliefs or ambiguity. Intuitively, imposing strong assumptions on the beliefs held by agents can lead to counter-monotonic allocations; there, the agents bet against each other due to belief heterogeneity instead of risk-seeking attitudes. ${ }^{18}$ We hope that further investigations will shed light on this issue, and we believe that a characterization of the betting behaviour for agents under ambiguity may also benefit from studying jackpot and scapegoat allocations. On this last point, as discussed in Remark 1, the concept of jackpot and scapegoat allocations are well suited for situations with no fixed probability.

# Appendices
## A Three technical lemmas

We first provide three technical lemmas that are useful in the proofs of our main results. Denote by $\mathcal{L}$ the set of all random variables $X$ such that there exists a standard uniform random variable $U$ independent of $X$; that is, Assumption ER holds for $X$ being any element of $\mathcal{L}$.

Lemma 1. Let $X_{1} \in \mathcal{L}$ have distribution $F_{1}$. For any distribution $F$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ with the first marginal $F_{1}$, there exists a random vector $\left(X_{2}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ such that $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ has distribution $F$.

Proof. Since $X_{1} \in \mathcal{L}$, we can always generate a sequence $U_{2}, \ldots, U_{n}$ of standard uniform random variables $U_{2}, \ldots, U_{n}$ from the standard uniform random variable $U_{1}$ independent of $X_{1}$; see e.g., Delbaen (2012, Theorem 1).

Let $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ be a random vector with distribution $F$. Let $X_{2}=F_{Y_{2} \mid Y_{1}}^{-1}\left(U_{2} \mid X_{1}\right)$ where $F_{Y_{2} \mid Y_{1}}^{-1}(\cdot \mid y)$ is the regular conditional quantile function of $Y_{2}$ given $Y_{1}=y$, which is well defined for almost every $y \in \mathbb{R}$. It is easy to check that $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=}\left(Y_{1}, Y_{2}\right)$. Similarly, we can construct $X_{j}$ for $j=3, \ldots, n$ by letting

$$
X_{j}=F_{Y_{j} \mid Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{j-1}}\left(U_{j} \mid X_{1}, \ldots, X_{j-1}\right)
$$

where $F_{Y_{j} \mid Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{j-1}}\left(\cdot \mid y_{1}, \ldots, y_{j-1}\right)$ is the quantile function of $Y_{j}$ given $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{j-1}\right)=\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{j-1}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{j-1}$. By construction, we have $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=}\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right) \sim F$.

Lemma 2. Fix an atomless probability space. For any $X \in \mathcal{L}$ and $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathcal{X}^{n}$, there exist $\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}^{n}$ and a standard uniform random variable $U$ such that $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right) \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=}$ $\left(X, X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $U$ is independent of $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$.

Proof. Let $H: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be the joint distribution of $\left(X, X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$. Define $H^{\prime}: \mathbb{R}^{n+2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as $H^{\prime}\left(x, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, u\right)=H\left(x, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) u$. It is clear that $H^{\prime}$ is the joint distribution on $\mathbb{R}^{n+2}$. By Lemma 1, we can find a vector $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}, U\right) \sim H^{\prime}$. Hence, we have $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right) \sim H$, $U \sim \mathrm{U}[0,1]$ and $U$ is independent of $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$.

For the next lemma, recall the definition of $\rho_{h}$, which, for $X \geq 0$, is given by

$$
\rho_{h}(X)=\int X \mathrm{~d}(h \circ \mathbb{P})=\int_{0}^{\infty} h(\mathbb{P}(X>x)) \mathrm{d} x
$$

where $h:[0,1] \rightarrow[0,1]$ is an increasing function with $h(0)=0=1-h(1)$, called a probability weighting function. For $h$ being the identity on $[0,1]$ we have $\rho_{h}(X)=\mathbb{E}[X]$.

Lemma 3. Suppose that the utility functions $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n}$ and the probability weighting functions $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{n}$ are continuous. For $X \in L_{+}^{\infty} \cap \mathcal{L}$ and $\mathcal{X}=L_{+}^{\infty}$, the set

$$
\operatorname{UPS}(X)=\left\{\left(\rho_{h_{1}}\left(u_{1}\left(X_{1}\right)\right), \ldots, \rho_{h_{n}}\left(u_{n}\left(X_{2}\right)\right)\right):\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)\right\}
$$

is compact (i.e., closed and bounded). In particular, for $\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$, the maximization

$$
\max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \rho_{h_{i}}\left(u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right)
$$

is attainable.
Proof. Let $m$ be the essential supremum of $X$. Since distributions in the set

$$
\left\{\text { distribution of }\left(X, X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right):\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)\right\}
$$

are all supported on the bounded region $[0, m]^{n+1}$, it is compact. Hence, any sequence of such distributions has a weak limit, which is supported on the set

$$
A:=\left\{\left(x, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in[0, \infty)^{n+1}: x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}=x\right\}
$$

Take any sequence of points $\mathbf{v}_{1}, \mathbf{v}_{2}, \ldots$ in $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$ that converges to $\mathbf{v}_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and let $\mathbf{X}^{(1)}, \mathbf{X}^{(2)}, \ldots$ be the random vectors in $\mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ with the utility vectors $\mathbf{v}_{1}, \mathbf{v}_{2}, \ldots$, respectively. Let $F$ be a weak limit of the sequence of distributions of the random vectors $\left(X, \mathbf{X}^{(1)}\right),\left(X, \mathbf{X}^{(2)}\right), \ldots$, which we argued above to exist. Note that the first marginal of $F$ is the distribution of $X$. By Lemma 1, there exists a random vector $\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ such that $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ has distribution $F$. Since $F$ is supported on $A$, we know that $\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$. Moreover, for each $i$, since $u_{i}$ on $[0, \infty)$ and $h_{i}$ on $[0,1]$ are continuous, the function $Y \mapsto \rho_{h_{i}}\left(u_{i}(Y)\right)$ is continuous with respect to weak convergence by Theorem 4 of Wang et al. (2020). Therefore, $\mathbf{v}_{0}=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathbf{v}_{j}=\left(\rho_{h_{1}}\left(u_{1}\left(X_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right), \ldots, \rho_{h_{n}}\left(u_{n}\left(X_{n}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right)$, which shows $\mathbf{v}_{0} \in \operatorname{UPS}(X)$. The boundedness statement follows by noting that $\rho_{h_{i}}\left(u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right) \leq$ $\rho_{h_{i}}\left(u_{i}(X)\right)$ due to monotonicity, which is finite for each $i \in[n]$. The last statement on maximization follows from the compactness of $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$.

Lemma 3 implies in particular that the maxima

$$
\max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right] \text { and } \max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \rho_{h}\left(u\left(X_{i}\right)\right)
$$

are attainable under Assumptions ER, EURS (for the first max), and H-RDU (for the second max).

Moreover, individually rational Pareto-optimal allocations always exist, as summarized in the next lemma.

Lemma 4. Suppose that Assumption ER hold, and either Assumption EURS or Assumption H-RDU holds. For any initial endowments, individually rational Pareto-optimal allocations exist.

Proof. Let $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)$ be the initial endowment vector. Recall that $\mathcal{U}_{i}$ for $i \in[n]$ is an EU preference functional under Assumption EURS and RDU preference function under Assumption H-RDU. By Lemma 3, the set $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$ is compact. Therefore, the set

$$
\operatorname{IR}(X):=\left\{\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right) \in \operatorname{UPS}(X): v_{i} \geq \mathcal{U}_{i}\left(\xi_{i}\right), i \in[n]\right\}
$$

is also compact. Maximizing $\sum_{i=1}^{n} v_{i}$ over $\operatorname{IR}(X)$ yields a point in $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$ attained by an individually rational Pareto-optimal allocation.

# B Proofs of all technical results
## B. 1 Proofs of results in Section 3

Proof of Proposition 1. This result follows by noting that the conditions in (3) are preserved under a probabilistic mixture.

Proof of Theorem 1. We explain that it suffices to prove the result by assuming that there exists a standard uniform random variable $U$ independent of $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$. This is due to Lemma 2. To see this, let $\left(X, X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=}\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ be as in Lemma 2. Suppose that we can prove the existence of the desired random vector $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ for the vector $\left(X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$. Note that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}^{\prime}=X=\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}$ almost surely. Moreover, $Y_{i} \geq_{c x} X_{i}^{\prime}$ is equivalent to $Y_{i} \geq_{c x} X_{i}$, since $X_{i} \stackrel{\mathrm{~d}}{=} X_{i}^{\prime}$. Therefore, $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ also satisfies all desired conditions for $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$. The rest of the proof follows the arguments in Section 3.3.

Proof of Corollary 1. Suppose that $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$ are bounded from below. There exist constants $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}$ such that $X_{1}+m_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}+m_{n}$ are nonnegative. Write $m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i}$. By Theorem 1, there exists a jackpot allocation $\left(Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X+m)$ such that $Z_{i} \geq_{c x} X_{i}+m_{i}$ for each $i \in[n]$. It follows that $Z_{i}-m_{i} \geq_{c x} X_{i}$ for $i \in[n]$. Hence, the counter-monotonic random vector $\left(Z_{1}-m_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}-m_{n}\right)$ satisfies the desired conditions in the corollary. The case that $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$ are bounded from above is analogous.

# B. 2 Proofs of results in Section 4 

Proof of Proposition 2. We first show the convexity of UPS $(X)$. Take $\mathbf{x} \in \operatorname{UPS}(X)$ and $\mathbf{y} \in$ $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$. By definition, there exist $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ and $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ such that

$$
\mathbf{x}=\left(\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}\left(X_{1}\right)\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[u_{n}\left(X_{n}\right)\right]\right) \text { and } \mathbf{y}=\left(\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}\left(Y_{1}\right)\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[u_{n}\left(Y_{n}\right)\right]\right)
$$

By Lemma 2, we can assume, without loss of generality, that there exists a uniform random variable $U$ independent of $\left(X, X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $\left(X, Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$; otherwise we can use $\left(X, X_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, X_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ and $\left(X, Y_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, Y_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ as in Lemma 2, and they will yield the same vectors of utility as $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$.

Consider their convex combination $\alpha \mathbf{x}+(1-\alpha) \mathbf{y}$ for some $\alpha \in[0,1]$. Let $Z_{i}=X_{i} \mathbb{1}_{\{U \leq \alpha\}}+$ $Y_{i} \mathbb{1}_{\{U>\alpha\}}$ for $i \in[n]$. Clearly, $\sum_{i=1}^{n} Z_{i}=X$; that is, $\left(Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$. Moreover, for every $i \in[n]$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Z_{i}\right)\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i} \mathbb{1}_{\{U \leq \alpha\}}+Y_{i} \mathbb{1}_{\{U>\alpha\}}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right) \mathbb{1}_{\{U \leq \alpha\}}+u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right) \mathbb{1}_{\{U>\alpha\}}\right]=\alpha \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]+(1-\alpha) \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $\alpha \mathbf{x}+(1-\alpha) \mathbf{y} \in \operatorname{UPS}(X)$, and $\operatorname{UPS}(X)$ is a convex set.
To show the convexity of $\operatorname{UPS}^{\lambda}(X)$, we follow the same arguments as above, with the additional observation that by using Proposition 1 on mixtures of jackpot allocations, $\left(Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}\right)$ constructed above is a jackpot allocation if $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ are both jackpot allocations.

Before proving Theorem 2, we first present a lemma, which gives (ii) $\Leftrightarrow$ (iii) in Theorem 2.
Lemma 5. Suppose that Assumption EURS hold and $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$. Then,

$$
\max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]
$$

Proof of Lemma 5. By Lemma 3, $\max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$ is attainable. Take any composition $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}$ satisfying $A_{i} \subseteq\left\{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)=V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right\}$ for $i \in[n]$. An explicit choice is

$$
A_{i}=\left\{\omega \in \Omega: i=\min \left(\underset{j \in[n]}{\arg \max } \lambda_{j} u_{j}(X(\omega))\right)\right\}, \quad i \in[n]
$$

By construction, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\max _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right] & \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)\right] \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, for any allocation $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$, we have

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right] \leq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]
$$

where the last inequality follows from the superadditivity of $V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$ because $V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$ is convex with $V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(0)=0$. Combining the above two inequalities, we get the desired result.

Proof of Theorem 2. We prove the theorem following the route (i) $\Rightarrow$ (ii) $\Rightarrow$ (iii) $\Rightarrow$ (i) $\Rightarrow$ (iv) $\Rightarrow$ (iii).
(i) $\Rightarrow$ (ii): By Proposition 2, the UPS of $X$ is a convex set. By the Hahn-Banach Theorem, for every Pareto-optimal allocation $\mathbf{X}$, there exists $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$ such that $\mathbf{X}$ is a $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$-optimal allocation.

The equivalence (ii) $\Leftrightarrow$ (iii) follows from Lemma 5 .
(iii) $\Rightarrow$ (i): If $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ has only positive components, it is clear that $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$-optimality implies Pareto optimality. Now suppose that some components of $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ are 0 . Without loss of generality, suppose that $\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{j}$ are positive, and $\lambda_{j+1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}$ are zero. Let $\mathbf{X}=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=$ $\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]$ and suppose that $\mathbf{Y}=\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ strictly dominates $\mathbf{X}$. Note that $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$-optimality of $\mathbf{X}$ implies that $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]$ for $i \in[j]$. Hence, $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]>\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$ must hold for some $i \geq j+1$, and this further implies $\mathbb{P}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{j} Y_{i}<X\right)>0$. Write $Y=\sum_{i=1}^{j} Y_{i}$. Note that $V_{\lambda}$ is the maximum of $j$ strictly increasing functions, and hence it is strictly increasing. Using $Y \leq X$ and $\mathbb{P}(Y<X)>0$, we have $\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(Y)\right]<\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]$. By Lemma 5 and $\lambda_{i}=0$ for $i \geq j+1$, we have

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(Y)\right]<\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]
$$

contradicting that $\mathbf{Y}$ dominates $\mathbf{X}$. Hence, $\mathbf{X}$ is Pareto optimal.
(i) $\Rightarrow$ (iv): By Theorem 1, there is a jackpot allocation $\mathbf{Y}=\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ such that $Y_{i} \geq_{c x} X_{i}$ holds for all $i \in[n]$. As $u_{i}$ is strictly convex, we have $\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$ by Pareto optimality of $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$. By Shaked and Shanthikumar (2007, Theorem 3.A.43), we obtain $Y_{i} \stackrel{\mathrm{~d}}{=}$

$X_{i}$. Next we show $\mathbf{X} \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=} \mathbf{Y}$. By Puccetti and Wang (2015, Theorem 3.3), $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ solves

$$
\inf \left\{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Z_{1}+\cdots+Z_{n}\right)^{2}\right]: Z_{i} \stackrel{\mathrm{~d}}{=} Y_{i}, i \in[n]\right\}
$$

Since $X_{i} \stackrel{\mathrm{~d}}{=} Y_{i}, i \in[n]$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} Y_{i}$, it is clear that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ also solves (12). Since $\mathcal{X}=L^{\infty}, \mathbb{E}\left[\left|Y_{i}\right|\right]<\infty$ for $i \in[n]$. Hence, we have that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ is counter-monotonic by Puccetti and Wang (2015, Theorem 3.3), which further gives $\mathbf{X} \stackrel{\mathrm{d}}{=} \mathbf{Y}$. Write

$$
\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)=\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right) \text { for some }\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}
$$

Using (iii), which is implied by (i), $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]$ for some $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$. It is clear that $\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)=\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}} \leq V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}$ for all $i \in[n]$. If there exists $i \in[n]$ such that $\mathbb{P}\left(\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}<V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)>0$, then $\mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]<\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]$. Hence,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]<\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right]
$$

contradicting $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$-optimality. Hence, (iv) holds.
The remaining (iv) $\Rightarrow$ (iii) follows by noting $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}=V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)$.
Proof of Theorem 3. We first show that $\mathrm{UPS}^{\mathrm{J}}(X) \subseteq \Delta_{n}(\mathbb{E}[u(X)])$. Let $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ be a jackpot allocation of $X$ and observe that by construction we have $\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right] \geq 0$ for $i \in[n]$, and

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}\left[u(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}[u(X)]
$$

Hence, $\left(\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{1}\right)\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{n}\right)\right]\right) \in \Delta_{n}(\mathbb{E}[u(X)])$. Conversely, let $\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$. By Assumption ER, we can take $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}$ independent of $X$ such that $\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right)=\theta_{i}$ for $i \in[n]$. This gives $\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)\right]=\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right) \mathbb{E}[u(X)]=\theta_{i} \mathbb{E}[u(X)]$ for $i \in[n]$. Therefore, $\mathrm{UPS}^{\mathrm{J}}(X)=\Delta_{n}(\mathbb{E}[u(X)])$. Note that every point in $\Delta_{n}(\mathbb{E}[u(X)])$ is in the UPF as they are not dominated by any other points in $\mathrm{UPS}^{\mathrm{J}}(X)$. Together with $\mathrm{UPS}^{\circ}(X) \subseteq \mathrm{UPS}^{\mathrm{J}}(X)$ guaranteed by Theorem 2, we can conclude that $\mathrm{UPS}^{\circ}(X)=\mathrm{UPS}^{\mathrm{J}}(X)=\Delta_{n}(\mathbb{E}[u(X)])$.

Proof of Proposition 3. Suppose that a jackpot allocation $x \mathbf{J}$ for $\mathbf{J} \in \mathbb{J}_{n}$ is strictly dominated by an allocation Y. By Theorem 1, Y is dominated by another jackpot allocation $x \mathbf{J}^{\prime}$ with $\mathbf{J}^{\prime} \in \mathbb{J}_{n}$. The strict domination of $x \mathbf{J}^{\prime}$ over $x \mathbf{J}$ implies $\mathbb{E}\left[x \mathbf{J}^{\prime}\right] \geq \mathbb{E}[x \mathbf{J}]$ componentwise with at least one component having strict inequality. This is not possible because both $\mathbf{J}$ and $\mathbf{J}^{\prime}$ have components summing to 1. Hence, $x \mathbf{J}$ cannot be strictly dominated by $\mathbf{Y}$, and it is Pareto optimal.

# B. 3 Proofs of results in Section 5 

Proof of Theorem 4. (i) Suppose that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ is an equilibrium but $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ is strictly dominated by another allocation $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$. There exists $j \in[n]$ such that $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{j}\left(Y_{j}\right)\right]>$ $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{j}\left(X_{j}\right)\right]$, and by the fact that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ is an equilibrium, it must hold that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{j}\right]>$ $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right] \geq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{j}\right]$. Since $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]$, there exists $i \in[n], i \neq j$ such that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right]<\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]$. By Pareto dominance we also have $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$. Let $\alpha=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{i}-\right.$ $\left.Y_{i}\right] / \mathbb{E}\left[X-Y_{i}\right]$. Since $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right]<\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]$, we have $\alpha \in(0,1]$. Let

$$
Z_{i}=Y_{i}+\left(X-Y_{i}\right) \alpha
$$

It is clear that $Y_{i} \leq Z_{i} \leq X$ and $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Z_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$. Recall that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right]<\mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]$, which implies $Q\left(Z_{i}>Y_{i}\right)>0$, and hence, $\mathbb{P}\left(Z_{i}>Y_{i}\right)>0$. Since $u_{i}$ is strictly increasing, we obtain $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Z_{i}\right)\right]>\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$, contradicting individual optimality for agent $i$.
(ii) Let $\mathbf{X}=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ be a Pareto-optimal allocation. By Theorem 2, we have $\mathbf{X}=X \mathbf{J}$ for some $\mathbf{J}=\left(\mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right) \in \mathbb{J}_{n}$ and $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$ such that $\left(\lambda_{1} u_{1}\left(X_{1}\right), \ldots, \lambda_{n} u_{n}\left(X_{n}\right)\right)=$ $V_{\mathbf{A}}(X) \mathbf{J}$. From the proof of Theorem 2, we can take $\lambda_{i}=0$ if $X_{i}=0$ (almost surely, omitted) and $\lambda_{i}>0$ if $X_{i}$ is not 0 .

Take the initial endowment $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$. We will show that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium for $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)$. Let $z=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\mathbf{A}}(X) / X\right]$ and $Q$ be given by (5). If $\xi_{i}=0$, it is clear that $X_{i}=0$ solves individual optimality. Next, we discuss the case that $\xi_{i}$ is not 0 , which implies $\lambda_{i}>0$. For such $i \in[n]$ let

$$
x_{i}=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]
$$

and notice that

$$
\lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\mathbf{A}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X \frac{V_{\mathbf{A}}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=z x_{i}
$$

For any $Y_{i}$ satisfying $0 \leq Y_{i} \leq X$ and the budget constraint $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right] \leq x_{i}$ we have

$$
\lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i} \frac{\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)}{Y_{i}}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i} \frac{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)}{X}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i} \frac{V_{\mathbf{A}}(X)}{X}\right]=x \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right] \leq z x_{i}=\lambda_{i} \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right]
$$

where the first inequality using the fact that $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ is increasing and the second that $\lambda_{i} u_{i} \leq V_{\mathbf{A}}$. Therefore, $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ satisfies individual optimality. Market clearance also holds, because $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}=1$. Therefore, $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ is an equilibrium allocation with itself being the initial endowments.

Proof of Theorem 5. The equivalence between (i), (ii), (iii) and (v) follows from Theorems 2 and 3. The equivalence between them and (iv) follows from Theorem 4.

Proof of Theorem 6. We first show (i). Denote by $x_{i}=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]=\theta_{i} \mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]$ and $z=\mathbb{E}[u(X) / X]>0$. It follows that

$$
\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}[X] \mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right)=x_{i}
$$

and hence, the budget constraint is satisfied for each $i \in[n]$. Moreover,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X \frac{u(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]=z x_{i}
$$

For any $Y_{i}$ satisfying $0 \leq Y_{i} \leq X$ and the budget constraint $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right] \leq x_{i}$, using the fact that $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ is increasing, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(Y_{i}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i} \frac{u\left(Y_{i}\right)}{Y_{i}}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i} \frac{u(X)}{X}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y_{i}\right] \leq z x_{i}=\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X_{i}\right)\right]
$$

Therefore, $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ satisfies individual optimality. Market clearance also holds, because $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}=1$

Next, we show part (iii), the uniqueness of the equilibrium price. Suppose that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium. By Theorem 5 we know it is a jackpot allocation. We can write $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)=\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right)$ for some $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}$ satisfying $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$ by the binding budget constraint. Let $P$ be the conditional probability measure of $\mathbb{P}$ on $\{X>0\}$, and let $p=\mathbb{P}(X>0)>0$. Let $\eta=\mathrm{d} Q / \mathrm{d} P$ and define a probability measure $R$ by

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} R}{\mathrm{~d} Q}=\frac{X}{c}, \text { where } c=\mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]
$$

and note that for any $A \in \mathcal{F}$, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)\right]=\frac{1}{p} \mathbb{E}^{P}\left[u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)\right]=\frac{1}{p} \mathbb{E}^{R}\left[\frac{\mathrm{~d} P}{\mathrm{~d} Q} \frac{\mathrm{~d} Q}{\mathrm{~d} R} u(X) \mathbb{1}_{A}\right]=\frac{1}{p} \mathbb{E}^{R}\left[\frac{c u(X)}{\eta X} \mathbb{1}_{A}\right]
$$

Denote by $Z=c u(X) /(\eta X)$. Individual optimality of $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ implies that for any $i \in[n]$ and any $A \in \mathcal{F}$ satisfying $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]$, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}^{R}\left[Z \mathbb{1}_{A}\right]=p \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)\right] \leq p \mathbb{E}\left[u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}^{R}\left[Z \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]
$$

Note that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right]$ is equivalent to $R(A) \leq R\left(\mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)$. Take $A \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $R(A)=R\left(A_{i}\right)$ and $Z$ and $\mathbb{1}_{A}$ are comonotonic; this is possible because $R$ is atomless. Suppose for

contradiction that $Z$ is not a constant. The Fréchet-Hoeffding inequality gives

$$
\operatorname{cov}\left(Z, \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right) \geq \operatorname{cov}\left(Z, \mathbb{1}_{A}\right) \geq 0
$$

and $\operatorname{cov}\left(Z, \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)>0$ if $R(A) \in(0,1)$. Since at least two of $\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}$ are not 0 , by the binding budget constraint, at least two of $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}$ have positive probability under $R$. Therefore, $\operatorname{cov}\left(Z, \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)>0$ for at least one $i$. However, $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{cov}\left(Z, \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=\operatorname{cov}(Z, 1)=0$, a contradiction. Hence, $Z$ is a constant. Therefore, $\eta$ is equal to a constant times $u(X) / X$, showing that $Q$ has the form (6).

Finally, part (ii) follows immediately from (iii), by noting that for the unique price $Q$, there can only be one maximum utility value for every agent. If only one of $\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}$ is not zero, say $\xi_{1}=X$, then the allocation is uniquely given by $(X, 0, \ldots, 0)$, and hence the unique vector of utilities.

Proof of Proposition 4. Without loss of generality, we can assume $\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{1}\right]>0$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{2}\right]>0$; otherwise $(X, 0)$ or $(0, X)$ is an equilibrium allocation with any equilibrium price absolutely continuous with respect to $\mathbb{P}$. Moreover, we can assume $\mathbb{P}(X=0)=0$, because the allocation on the event $\{X=0\}$ is trivial.

For a random variable $W$, a tail event is an event $A$ such that for some $w \in \mathbb{R}, W \geq w$ on $A$ and $W \leq w$ on $A^{c}$. In an atomless probability space, a tail event with any given probability $\lambda \in(0,1)$ exists, as shown by Wang and Zitikis (2021). Let $W=u_{1}(X) / u_{2}(X)$. For $\lambda \in(0,1)$, let $\left(A^{\lambda}\right)_{\lambda \in(0,1)}$ be an increasing family of tail events of $W$ such that $\mathbb{P}\left(A^{\lambda}\right)=\lambda$. We can check that the mapping $\lambda \mapsto \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A^{\lambda}}\right]$ is continuous (because $\lambda \mapsto Q\left(A^{\lambda}\right)$ is continuous) and its range is the open interval $\left(0, \mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]\right)$. Therefore, there exists $\lambda^{*} \in(0,1)$ such that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A^{\lambda}}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{1}\right] \in\left(0, \mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]\right)$. Write $A_{1}=A^{\lambda}$ and $A_{2}=\left(A^{\lambda}\right)^{c}$. By definition of the tail event, for some $w^{*} \geq 0$, we have $W \geq w^{*}$ on $A_{1}$ and $W \leq w^{*}$ on $A_{2}$.

We will show that $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)=\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}, Q\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium. The budget condition is satisfied by $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{1}\right]$ and $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]-\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{1}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{2}\right]$. Market clearance is immediate. It remains to show individual optimality. Denote by $z=\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}(X) / X\right]$. For any $Y$ with $0 \leq Y \leq X$ such that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{1}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right]$, using that $x \mapsto u_{1}(x) / x$ is increasing, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}(Y)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{1}(Y)}{Y}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{1}(X)}{X}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}\left(X_{1}\right)\right]
$$

Hence, $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}(Y)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{1}\left(X_{1}\right)\right]$. For any $Y$ with $0 \leq Y \leq X$ such that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]$,

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2}(Y)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X}\right] & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{w^{*} u_{1}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right] \\
& =w^{*} z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, $\mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]$ implies $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[Y \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[(X-Y) \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2}(Y)\right] & \leq w^{*} z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[(X-Y) \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{X-Y}{X} w^{*} u_{1}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{X-Y}{X} u_{2}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{u_{2}(X)}{X} \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{2}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2}(Y)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{2}\left(X_{2}\right)\right]$. Therefore, individual optimality holds, and $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}, Q\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium.

# B. 4 Proofs of results in Section 6 

Proof of Theorem 7. In (i) and (ii) below, since $X$ takes values in $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$, we can without loss of generality let $u$ be the identity function. Hence, the preference functional of each agent is $\rho_{h}$.
(i) Write $\mathbf{J}=\left(\mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right)$. First, for each $i \in[n]$, since $h=\bar{h}$ on $[0,1 / n]$ and $\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right)=1 / n$, we have

$$
\rho_{h}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=\int h\left(\mathbb{P}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}>x\right)\right) \mathrm{d} x=\int \bar{h}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}>x\right)\right) \mathrm{d} x=\rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)
$$

Moreover,

$$
\rho_{h}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=\rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=\int \bar{h}\left(\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{P}(X>x)\right) \mathrm{d} x
$$

Next, we will show that

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{h}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=\sup _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X_{i}\right)
$$

and since $h \leq \bar{h}$, this gives sum-optimality of $\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right)$. To show (14), it suffices to consider jackpot allocations $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ because the preference functional $\rho_{\bar{h}}$ is risk seeking (Chew et al., 1987), and we can apply Theorem 1. Using the representation $\left(X \mathbb{1}_{B_{1}}, \ldots, X \mathbb{1}_{B_{n}}\right)$ of jackpot allo-

cations, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)} \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X_{i}\right) & =\sup _{\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}} \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{B_{i}}\right) \\
& =\sup \left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \int_{0}^{\infty} \bar{h}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{B_{i}}>x\right)\right) \mathrm{d} x:\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}\right\} \\
& \leq \int_{0}^{\infty} \sup \left\{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \bar{h}\left(p_{i}\right): \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_{i}=\mathbb{P}(X>x)\right\} \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} n \bar{h}\left(\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{P}(X>x)\right) \mathrm{d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality is due to concavity of $\bar{h}$. Using (13), we get (14), and hence the allocation $\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, X \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right)$ is sum-optimal and Pareto optimal.
(ii) Note that since $\bar{h}$ is strictly concave on $(0,1 / n), t \mapsto t \bar{h}(x / t)$ is strictly increasing in $t \geq 1$ for each $x \in(0,1 / n)$. This implies $n \bar{h}(x / n)>h(x)$ for all $x \in(0,1)$. Hence,

$$
\frac{1}{n} \int_{0}^{\infty} \bar{h}(\mathbb{P}(X>x)) \mathrm{d} x<\int_{0}^{\infty} \bar{h}\left(\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{P}(X>x)\right) \mathrm{d} x
$$

As a consequence,

$$
\rho_{h}(X / n) \leq \rho_{\bar{h}}(X / n)=\frac{1}{n} \int_{0}^{\infty} \bar{h}(\mathbb{P}(X>x)) \mathrm{d} x<\int_{0}^{\infty} \bar{h}\left(\frac{1}{n} \mathbb{P}(X>x)\right) \mathrm{d} x=\rho_{h}\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)
$$

This shows the strict dominance.
(iii) Note that $h(t / n) / h(t)<1$ for $t \in(0,1)$ because $h$ is concave (thus strictly increasing) on $[0,1 / n]$. Together with the continuity of $h$ and condition (10), we get $\sup _{t \in(0,1)} h(t / n) / h(t)<1$. Hence, we can take $\theta<1$ such that

$$
\sup _{t \in(0,1)} \frac{h(t / n)}{h(t)}<\theta
$$

and take $y_{0}>0$ such that $u(x / n)>\theta u(x)$ for $x \geq y_{0}$, also guaranteed by (10). Note that $X \geq y_{0}$ implies $u(X / n) \geq \theta u(X)$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\rho_{h}\left(u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)\right) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} h\left(\mathbb{P}\left(u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{A}\right)>x\right)\right) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} h\left(\frac{\mathbb{P}(u(X)>x)}{n}\right) \mathrm{d} x \\
& <\theta \int_{0}^{\infty} h(\mathbb{P}(u(X)>x)) \mathrm{d} x=\rho_{h}(\theta u(X)) \leq \rho_{h}(u(X / n))
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$ yields higher utility for each agent than $X \mathbf{J}$ does, and thus strict domination holds.
(iv) Denote by $y=X / n>0$ and $Z^{\varepsilon}$ the first component of $\overline{\mathbf{X}}-\varepsilon \mathbf{1}+n \varepsilon \mathbf{J}$. We can immediately

compute

$$
\rho_{h}\left(u\left(Z^{\varepsilon}\right)\right)=u(y-\varepsilon)+(u(y+(n-1) \varepsilon)-u(y-\varepsilon)) h(1 / n)
$$

Taking derivative yields

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \varepsilon} \rho_{h}\left(u\left(Z^{\varepsilon}\right)\right)=-u^{\prime}(y-\varepsilon)+((n-1) u^{\prime}(y+(n-1) \varepsilon)+u^{\prime}(y-\varepsilon)) h(1 / n)
$$

which converges to $n u^{\prime}(y)(h(1 / n)-1 / n)$ as $\varepsilon \downarrow 0$. Using $h(1 / n)>1 / n$, which is implied by the strict concavity of $h$ on $(0,1 / n)$, we get that $\mathrm{d} \rho_{h}\left(u\left(Z^{\varepsilon}\right)\right) / \mathrm{d} \varepsilon>0$ for $\varepsilon>0$ small, and hence $\rho_{h}\left(u\left(Z^{\varepsilon}\right)\right)>u(y)$ for $\varepsilon>0$ small enough. This shows that $\overline{\mathbf{X}}-\varepsilon \mathbf{1}+n \varepsilon \mathbf{J}$ strictly dominates $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$.

Proof of the statement in Example 5. Let $v=u\left(y_{0}\right)$. The allocation $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$ yields the maximum utility $v$ to all agents, and hence it is Pareto optimal. To show strict domination, let $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ be a jackpot allocation and $p_{i}=\mathbb{P}\left(X_{i}>0\right)$ for $i \in[n]$. With this allocation, agent $i$ has utility

$$
\int_{0}^{v} \bar{h}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(u\left(X_{i}\right)>x\right)\right) \mathrm{d} x \leq v h\left(p_{i}\right)
$$

Since at least one $p_{i}$ is less than or equal to $1 / n$, the condition $h(1 / n)<1$ guarantees that at least one agent has a utility less than $v$, and thus the jackpot allocation is strictly dominated by $\overline{\mathbf{X}}$.

Proof of Proposition 5. Without loss of generality, assume that $u$ is the identity on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$. The budget conditions and market clearance hold by construction of $x \mathbf{J}$. We only need to show individual optimality. Write $\left(\mathbb{1}_{A_{1}}, \ldots, \mathbb{1}_{A_{n}}\right)=\mathbf{J}$. Note that for any random variable $Y$ taking values in $[0,1]$ we have $Y \leq_{\mathrm{cx}} \mathbb{1}_{A}$ where $\mathbb{P}(A)=\mathbb{E}[Y]$. Therefore, we have $\rho_{\bar{h}}(Y) \leq \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(\mathbb{1}_{A}\right)=\bar{h}(\mathbb{E}[Y])$ because $\rho_{\bar{h}}$ represents a risk-seeking preference. It follows that for any random variable $X_{i}$ in $[0, x]$ satisfying the constraint $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$, we have

$$
\rho_{h}\left(X_{i}\right) \leq \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(X_{i}\right) \leq \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(x \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)=x \bar{h}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=x h\left(\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}\right)\right)=\rho_{h}\left(x \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}\right)
$$

This extends to the case $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{i}\right]<\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$ by monotonicity. Therefore, individual optimality holds, showing that $(x \mathbf{J}, \mathbb{P})$ is a competitive equilibrium.

# C Technical background on counter-monotonicity 

We provide some technical background on counter-monotonicity. First, Dall'Aglio (1972) obtained some necessary conditions for counter-monotonicity in dimensions more than two. As standard in probability theory, a random variable is non-degenerate if it is not almost surely a constant.

Proposition 6 (Dall'Aglio (1972)). If at least three of $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$ are non-degenerate, countermonotonicity of $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ is equivalent to that one of the following two cases holds true:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{P}\left(X_{i}>\text { ess-inf } X_{i}, X_{j}>\text { ess-inf } X_{j}\right)=0 \text { for all } i \neq j \\
& \mathbb{P}\left(X_{i}<\text { ess-sup } X_{i}, X_{j}<\text { ess-sup } X_{j}\right)=0 \text { for all } i \neq j
\end{aligned}
$$

A necessary condition for (15) is $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{i}>\right.$ ess-inf $\left.X_{i}\right) \leq 1$, and a necessary condition for (16) is $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{i}<\right.$ ess-sup $\left.X_{i}\right) \leq 1$.

The alternative formulation (3) of jackpot allocations in Section 3 directly follows from Proposition 6 .

Recall that $\Pi_{n}$ is the set of all $n$-compositions of $\Omega$. The next proposition, which is a reformulation of Lauzier et al. (2023a, Theorem 1), simplifies the stochastic representation of countermonotonicity. Note that the equalities below, as well as other equalities and inequalities between random variables, are understood to hold almost surely. In the next result, $\mathcal{X}=L^{1}$.

Proposition 7. For $X \in \mathcal{X}$, suppose that at least three of $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ are nondegenerate. Then, $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ is counter-monotonic if and only if there exist constants $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}$ and $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { either } & X_{i}=(X-m) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}+m_{i} \quad \text { for all } i \in[n] \text { with } m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} \leq \text { ess-inf } X \\
\text { or } & X_{i}=(X-m) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}+m_{i} \quad \text { for all } i \in[n] \text { with } m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} \geq \text { ess-sup } X
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition 7. The "if" part follows from the fact that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}=X$ and Proposition 6. We will show the "only if" part. Assume that $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$ is counter-monotonic. By Lauzier et al. (2023a, Theorem 1), there exists $\left(A_{1}, \ldots, A_{n}\right) \in \Pi_{n}$ such that

$$
X_{i}=(X-m) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}+m_{i} \quad \text { for all } i \in[n]
$$

where either $m_{i}=$ ess-inf $X_{i}$ for all $i \in[n]$ or $m_{i}=$ ess-sup $X_{i}$ for all $i \in[n]$, and $m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i}$. If $m_{i}=$ ess-inf $X_{i}$ for all $i \in[n]$, we have $m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{ess}-\inf \left(X_{i}\right) \leq \operatorname{ess}-\inf \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}\right)=$ ess-inf $X$. If $m_{i}=$ ess-sup $X_{i}$ for all $i \in[n]$, we have $m=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{ess}-\sup \left(X_{i}\right) \geq \operatorname{ess}-\sup \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}\right)=$ ess-sup $X$.

The allocation $(X, 0, \ldots, 0)$ is counter-monotonic by taking $A=\Omega$ and $m=m_{1}=$ ess-inf $X$, and it is trivial to verify that it is also comonotonic. Notice now that the allocations defined in equation (17) and (18) reflect the conditions in Proposition 6. In (17), for almost every $\omega \in \Omega$, at

most one agent receives more than their essential infimum. Conversely, in (18), at most one agent receives less than their essential supremum.

# D Some extensions of Theorem 7 

We briefly discuss a few dimensions in which the statements in Theorem 7 can readily be generalized. We did not pursue these generalizations because they do not seem to offer stronger empirical relevance than Assumption H-RDU.
(a) Assumption H-RDU allows for $h$ to be concave. In this case, $\bar{h}=h$, and the agents are risk seeking for payoffs valued in $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$.
(b) By inspecting the proof of Theorem 7, it suffices to require $h=\bar{h}$ on $[0,1 / n]$, and whether $h$ is concave-convex beyond $1 / n$ is irrelevant.
(c) The result remains true if $u$ is convex on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ instead of being linear, following the same proof, by noting that an agent with a convex utility function and the probability weighting function $\bar{h}$ is risk seeking, which is the main step to apply Theorem 1.
(d) A careful inspection of the proofs of main results reveals that, for most of our results on riskseeking EU agents, it suffices to assume that $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ is increasing instead of the convexity of $u$ (this condition is weaker than convexity with $u(0)=0$ ). Moreover, for the RDU agents in Assumption H-RDU, we can use this condition on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$ instead of linearity, and the results in Theorem 7 hold true.

We formally prove the assertion in (d) below. Let $u$ be an increasing function with $u(0)=0$ and $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ is increasing. We first show an analogue of Theorem 1. Let $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ be as in the proof of Theorem 1. Note that

$$
u\left(Y_{i}\right)=u\left(X \mathbb{1}_{\left\{Z_{i-1} \leq U<Z_{i}\right\}}\right)=u(X) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{Z_{i-1} \leq U<Z_{i}\right\}} \geq \frac{X u\left(X_{i}\right)}{X_{i}} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{Z_{i-1} \leq U<Z_{i}\right\}} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{i}>0\right\}}
$$

Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[u\left(Y_{i}\right) \mid X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right] & \geq \frac{X u\left(X_{i}\right)}{X_{i}} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{i}>0\right\}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{1}_{\left\{Z_{i-1} \leq U<Z_{i}\right\}} \mid X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right] \\
& =\frac{X u\left(X_{i}\right)}{X_{i}} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{i}>0\right\}} \frac{X_{i}}{X} \\
& =u\left(X_{i}\right) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{i}>0\right\}}=u\left(X_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows $u\left(Y_{i}\right) \geq_{\mathrm{icx}} u\left(X_{i}\right)$, where $\geq_{\mathrm{icx}}$ is increasing convex order (meaning $\mathbb{E}\left[\phi\left(Y_{i}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[\phi\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$ for all increasing convex $\phi$ ). This implies $\rho_{\bar{h}}\left(u\left(Y_{i}\right)\right) \geq \rho_{\bar{h}}\left(u\left(X_{i}\right)\right)$ because $\rho_{\bar{h}}$ is increasing in convex order (e.g., Wang et al. 2020, Theorem 3), and increasing convex order can be decomposed into convex order and first-order stochastic dominance (e.g., Shaked and Shanthikumar 2007, Theorem 4.A.6). Therefore, the jackpot allocation $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)$ dominates $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$, and for sum-optimality it suffices to consider jackpot allocations. The rest of the proof follows the same arguments in the proof of parts (i) and (ii) of Theorem 7 with $X$ replaced by $u(X)$. Parts (iii) and (iv) do not rely on the properties of $u$ on $\left[0, x_{0}\right]$.

We finally note that if $u$ is convex on $[0, a]$ and concave on $[a, \infty)$, then $x \mapsto u(x) / x$ is increasing on some interval $[0, b]$ with $b \geq a$ (often $b>a$ ).

# E On the existence of competitive equilibria for EU agents 

For the interested reader, we discuss the existence of competitive equilibria in the setting of Section 5 (under Assumption EURS) for a given initial endowment $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$. We outline a general approach under some assumptions, and prove the existence of competitive equilibria in the special case of proportional endowments.

First, we make an assumption of no-ties in the weighted utility functions.
Assumption NT. For $i \neq j,\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}_{+} : \lambda_{i} u_{i}(x)=\lambda_{j} u_{j}(x)\right)\}$ is finite for any $\lambda_{i}, \lambda_{j}>0$, and $X$ is continuously distributed.

A simple example of utility functions satisfying Assumption NT is that agent $i$ is more risk seeking than agent $i+1$ for $i \in[n]$; that is, $u_{i}=T_{i} \circ u_{i+1}$ for some increasing and strictly convex function $T_{i}$ for $i \in[n-1]$. In this case, for any $\lambda_{i}, \lambda_{j}>0, i \neq j$, we have that $\lambda_{i} u_{i}$ and $\lambda_{j} u_{j}$ cross at most once under Assumption EURS. For instance, this holds for $u_{i}(x)=x^{\alpha_{i}}, i \in[n]$, with distinct values of $\alpha_{i}$. For an illustration, see the left panel of Figure 2.

For any given $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$, define the sets $A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left\{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)=V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)\right\}$ for $i \in[n]$ and let $\mathbf{J}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left(\mathbb{1}_{A_{1}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}, \ldots, \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right)$. For $i \neq j$, Assumption NT implies that $\mathbb{P}\left(\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)=\lambda_{j} u_{j}(X)\right)=0$ because $X$ is continuously distributed. Hence, $\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \cap A_{j}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\right)=0$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}=1$ (almost surely). Thus, $X \mathbf{J}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$ is a jackpot allocation.

Next, we introduce three useful objects. Define a probability measure $Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$ by

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}{\mathrm{d} \mathbb{P}}=\frac{V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X)}{X} \frac{1}{\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) / X\right]} \quad \text { with the convention } 0 / 0=0
$$

a function $f: \Delta_{n} \rightarrow \Delta_{n}$ by

$$
f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\left(\frac{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]}, \ldots, \frac{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]}\right)=\frac{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}\left[X \mathbf{J}^{\lambda}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]}, \quad \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}
$$

and a function $g: \Delta_{n} \rightarrow \Delta_{n}$ by

$$
g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\left(\frac{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}\left[\xi_{1}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]}, \ldots, \frac{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}\left[\xi_{n}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]}\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}
$$

Note that $\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\lambda}}[X]>0$ holds under Assumption EURS. Our goal is to find $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$ such that $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$. The next proposition justifies that finding such $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ is sufficient for finding a competitive equilibrium.

Proposition 8. Under Assumptions EURS and NT, if $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$ and $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$, then $\left(X \mathbf{J}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium for the vector of initial endowments $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{A}_{n}(X)$.

Proof of Proposition 8. Write $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)=\left(X \mathbf{J}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\right)$ and $\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right)=\boldsymbol{\lambda}$. The equality $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$ implies $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$ for $i \in[n]$. Let $z=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) / X\right]$. Fix $i \in[n]$. For any $Y$ with $0 \leq Y \leq X$ such that $\mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]$, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}(Y)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(Y)}{Y}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)}{X}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[Y \frac{V_{\lambda}(X)}{X}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}[Y] \leq z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[\xi_{i}\right]=z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]
$$

Moreover, since $A_{i}^{\lambda}=\left\{\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X)=V_{\lambda}(X)\right\}$, we have $V_{\lambda}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}}=\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}}=\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)$, and this implies

$$
z \mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}} \frac{V_{\lambda}(X)}{X}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]
$$

Hence, $\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(Y_{i}\right)\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(X_{i}\right)\right]$ and thus $X_{i}$ satisfies individual optimality for agent $i$. The market clearance condition $\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_{i}=X$ holds true because $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{1}_{A_{\lambda}^{\lambda}}=1$. Therefore, $\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}, Q\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium.

The remaining task is to find $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ with $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$. We do not know a general solution to this problem, but in the simplified scenario of proportional endowments, the problem can be solved.

Assumption PE. The initial endowment vector $\left(\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right)$ is equal to $\left(\theta_{1} X, \ldots, \theta_{n} X\right)$ for some $\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$.

Under Assumption PE, we have $g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right)$ for any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$. In this situation, we can show that $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$ holds, through a technique established by Jamison and Ruckle (1976).

Proposition 9. If Assumptions EURS, NT and PE hold, then there exists a competitive equilibrium of the form $\left(X \mathbf{J}^{\lambda}, Q^{\lambda}\right)$ for some $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$.

Proof of Proposition 9. A face of $\Delta_{n}$ is the set $\Delta_{n}^{D}=\left\{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}: x_{j}=0\right.$ for $\left.j \in D\right\}$ for some $D \subseteq[n]$. Lemma 6 below guarantees that $f$ is a continuous function that carries each face of $\Delta_{n}$ into itself. This condition allows us to apply Jamison and Ruckle (1976, Lemma 2.1), which implies that $f$ is surjective. Hence, there exists $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$ such that $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right)=g(\boldsymbol{\lambda})$. By Proposition $8,\left(X \mathbf{J}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}, Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\right)$ is a competitive equilibrium.

Lemma 6. If Assumptions EURS and NT hold, then $f$ is a continuous function that carries each face of $\Delta_{n}$ into itself.

Proof of Lemma 6. For $i \in[n]$, define $f_{i}: \Delta_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$by $f_{i}(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right]$ for $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}$. We have

$$
f_{i}(\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\mathbb{E}^{Q^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[V_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\lambda_{i} u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right]
$$

Let $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{n}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}=\left(\zeta_{1}, \ldots, \zeta_{n}\right) \in \Delta_{n}$ be such that $\|\boldsymbol{\lambda}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}\|:=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\lambda_{i}-\zeta_{i}\right|<\varepsilon$. As $X$ is continuously distributed and $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n}$ are continuous, Assumption NT implies

$$
p:=\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \cup A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \cap A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}\right)=\mathbb{P}\left(X \in \bigcup_{x^{*}: \lambda_{i} u_{i}\left(x^{*}\right)=\lambda_{j} u_{j}\left(x^{*}\right)}\left\{x^{*}-c_{1} \varepsilon<x<x^{*}+c_{1} \varepsilon\right\}\right)<c_{2} \varepsilon
$$

for some $c_{1}, c_{2}>0$, because switching from $A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$ to $A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}$ or back can only happen at points in some neighborhoods of $\left\{x: \lambda_{i} u_{i}(x)=\lambda_{j} u_{j}(x)\right\}$. This implies that $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \mapsto \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}(X) \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right]$ is continuous, further guaranteeing that $f_{i}$ is continuous. Therefore, $\hat{f}:=\sum_{i=1}^{n} f_{i}$ is also a continuous function. Moreover, under Assumption EURS, we have $\hat{f}>0$. Since $f=\left(f_{1} / \hat{f}, \ldots, f_{n} / \hat{f}\right)$, we know that $f$ is continuous. Moreover, if $\lambda_{i}=0$, then $\mathbb{P}\left(A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\right)=0$ and thus $\mathbb{E}^{Q}\left[X \mathbb{1}_{A_{i}^{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}\right] / \mathbb{E}^{Q}[X]=0$. Hence, for any face $\Delta_{n}^{D}$ and $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Delta_{n}^{D}$, we have $f(\boldsymbol{\lambda}) \in \Delta_{n}^{D}$.

abstract:
We analyze Pareto optimality and competitive equilibria in a risk-exchange
economy, where either all agents are risk seeking in an expected utility model,
or they exhibit local risk-seeking behaviour in a rank-dependent utility model.
A novel mathematical tool, the counter-monotonic improvement theorem, states
that for any nonnegative allocation of the aggregate random payoff, there
exists a counter-monotonic random vector, called a jackpot allocation, that is
componentwise riskier than the original allocation, and thus preferred by
risk-seeking agents. This result allows us to characterize Pareto optimality,
the utility possibility frontier, and competitive equilibria with risk-seeking
expected utility agents, and prove the first and second fundamental theorems of
welfare economics in this setting. For rank-dependent utility agents that are
neither risk averse or risk seeking, we show that jackpot allocations can be
Pareto optimal for small-scale payoffs, but for large-scale payoffs they are
dominated by proportional allocations, thus explaining the often-observed
small-stake gambling behaviour in a risk sharing context. Such jackpot
allocations are also equilibrium allocations for small-scale payoffs when there
is no aggregate uncertainty.
